Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> Hi David,
>
> On 6/28/06, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>   
>> ES,
>>
>> There aren't really _required_ steps for a test, so this base class may
>> be establishing too many requirements on your classes.  I'd be
>> interested to hear a little more about your goals, to see if a different
>> approach more along JUnit's grain might be what you need.
>>
>> For example, most of my test classes do not include @BeforeClass or
>> @AfterClass, and many do not have @After.  You'll also have the issue
>> that @BeforeClass and @AfterClass need to be on static methods which
>> cannot be abstract.
>>
>> That said, depending on your goals, the following approach _might_ be
>> useful:
>>
>> public abstract class ApiTestBase
>> {
>>   @Before public void preTest() { doPreTest(); }
>>   public abstract void doPreTest();
>>   // etc
>> }
>>     
>
>
> This approaches pretty much defeats the purpose of annotations, doesn't it?
>   

It seems to me that the original poster's goal was to accomplish 
something that was beyond the purpose of annotations (a compile-time 
check that every test class has a @Before method).

> I've had to do it many times, as have most TestNG users.
>   

You've had to do _this_ (a compile-time check that every test class has 
a @Before method), or something else that also involves annotations and 
inheritance? If it's something else, then please post about that 
something else on a new thread, and let's talk about it. If it's this, 
then please confirm, because that would be a new data point for me.

> Inheritance of annotations is really handy (and pretty easy to implement), I
> would strongly suggest you to take a shot at it :-)
>   


JUnit already has some features that involve inheritance and 
annotations, but probably not every conceivable one. If there are 
specific ones that are missing, let's talk about them!


David Saff
